contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=September 2008}} '''Girdwood''' is an unincorporated year-round [[ski resort]] community within the [[Anchorage, Alaska|Municipality of Anchorage]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Alaska]]. It lies in a valley in the [[Chugach Mountains]] near the end of the Turnagain Arm of [[Cook Inlet]], 36 miles (61 km) southeast of Anchorage proper. It is surrounded by seven permanent [[glacier]]s. Summer activities include hiking, fishing and rafting, but Girdwood is best known for winter [[skiing]] and [[snowboarding]] at [[Alyeska Resort]] on [[Mount Alyeska]]. Girdwood also hosts the Girdwood Forest Fair every summer. Girdwood has the northernmost rain forest in the world. ==History== Originally called "Glacier City," Girdwood was founded as a supply camp for [[Placer mining|placer]] [[Gold mining|gold miners]] with claims along the creeks feeding Turnagain Arm. It was renamed for Colonel James Girdwood, a [[Belfast]]-born, [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]] entrepreneur and linen merchant who staked the first four gold claims along Crow Creek in 1896. [[File:Senator Ted Stevens Girdwood Alaska house.jpg|thumb|right|Ted Stevens' Girdwood home is a fairly typical example of a home in Girdwood]] The town was moved 2.5 miles (4 km) up the valley after the devastating [[Good Friday Earthquake]] of 1964, when the land under the original townsite [[Subsidence|subsided]] into Turnagain Arm, putting much of the town below high tide. The land has not all since been reclaimed, as one can still see 'drowned' cabins in the marshy areas where the city formerly extended. Significant earthquakes are a relatively common occurrence for Girdwood and the Kenai peninsula. Evidence has been discovered that indicates the area has seen six major quakes in the past 3300 years.<ref>[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/research/external/reports/03HQGR0101.pdf "RECURRENT HOLOCENE PALEOSEISMICITY AND ASSOCIATED LAND / SEA LEVEL CHANGES IN THE GREATER ANCHORAGE AREA"]</ref> Girdwood was incorporated as a city in 1970 and became part of the Municipality of Anchorage when the Greater Anchorage Area Borough unified with the city of Anchorage in 1975. The town has served as a backdrop for at least two films: ''[[The Chechahcos]]'', a [[1924 in film|1924]] [[silent film]] about the [[Klondike Gold Rush]], and [[Warren Miller (director)|Warren Miller]]'s [[1997 in film|1997]] ''Snowriders II''. Girdwood was the home of Alaska's former senior [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Stevens]], and Girdwood found itself in the media spotlight when the construction projects on Stevens' home became the subject of a federal investigation. [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] gold and silver medal-winning skier [[Tommy Moe]] also called Girdwood home during his High School years where he attended Glacier Creek Academy. Girdwood was shown on [[CBS]] on January 20, 2008, as the Finish Line for ''[[The Amazing Race 12]]''. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Alaska-Community-External-References|Girdwood}} * [http://www.timberlinedrivebnb.com/girdwood.html Girdwood Information and Pictures] * [http://www.powdertour.com Social Community - Member submitted Girdwood Images] {{coord|60|56|33|N|149|09|59|W|type:city_region:US-AK|display=title}} [[Category:Anchorage metropolitan area]] [[Category:Populated places in Anchorage, Alaska]] [[Category:Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area]] {{AnchorageAK-geo-stub}}
